results.title: Britain on show
results.creator_credit: Rayant Pictures, Anthony Gilkison and John Durst
results.brief_description: Britain’s contribution to the Brussels Universal and International Exhibition of 1958. A picture of the British people and their achievements in modern agriculture, industry, science, technology, and public administration, through examples from the exhibition. Aspects of life and work today, including young people at university, engineers building an atomic power station, teenagers dancing in a London cellar, and the Comet jet airliner under construction. Commentary by Stanley Van Beers.

results.title: Britain now
results.creator_credit: Anglo-Scottish Pictures, Stuart Legg and John Spencer
results.brief_description: In 1945, Britain emerged from the war to find that, although victorious, there lay ahead a tremendous task of reconstruction; cities to be rebuilt, trade to be revived and exports to be stepped up. The film tells the story of Britain’s post-war recovery, thanks to the courage and determination of her people. Overseas, three great nations have achieved independence within the Commonwealth, and in the Dependencies, new constitutions are paving the way to self-government. Narrated by Leo Genn.

results.title: Britain is a garden
results.creator_credit: Rayant Pictures, British Travel and Holiday Association, Anthony Gilkison and John Durst
results.brief_description: A colorful array of floral gardens in Britain. Different styles of flower cultivation are illustrated, ranging from the wild loveliness of early spring flowers in the Scilly Isles to the delicacy of rose gardens in Northern Ireland; from London’s roof-top and window-box displays to the planned landscapes which are so much a feature of historic country houses in Britain. Includes the Chelsea Flower Show. Narrated by Deryck Guyler.

results.title: Britain down under
results.creator_credit: Frederick Daniel Productions and Una Daniel
results.brief_description: A tour of Tasmania showing various places of interest: life in the two main cities, Hobart and Launceston; the fishing and lobster industries; the raising of sheep and cattle on the rich pasture lands; hop growing; timber from the forests of the islands; tin mining, and the extensive hydro-electric schemes. The various tourist attractions of Tasmania are illustrated with views of coastal scenery and the rugged mountainous country. Also shown are the ruins of the historic penal colony at Port Arthur. Narrated by Jack Davey.

results.title: Britain's sporting heritage
results.brief_description: A montage of favourite sporting events in Britain. Athletics, tennis, skating, golf and cycling; team games including soccer and rugby, cricket and hockey. Famous sporting personalities and some young champions of the future in action.

results.title: Bristol: British city
results.creator_credit: World Wide Pictures, Alexander Shaw and Mary Francis
results.brief_description: The people of Bristol tell of their city, long since called the Maritime Capital of the West of England; a city with whose history many pioneers, adventurers and navigators, and many great moral and spiritual leaders have been associated. With its bustling life and half a million citizens, the city’s efficiency is still symbolised by the old phrase “shipshape and Bristol fashion”.

results.title: Bristol fashion
results.creator_credit: Associated British-Pathe, Terry Ashwood and Eric Fullilove
results.brief_description: The history and development of the Port of Bristol - the only major municipally owned port in Britain. Illustrates the facilities available in the city docks and at Avonmouth and Portishead, and discusses plans for the expansion of dock services. Sequences on the history of architecture of Bristol are interwoven.
